author: By Kathryn Shattuck
title: When Andrew Koji Isn’t Fighting Onscreen, He’s Memorizing a Poem
description: The star of the Max martial-arts drama “Warrior” starts his days with meditation and Morning Pages, and powers down with PlayStation.
content: In November, Andrew Koji wrapped the third season of “Warrior,” the martial-arts television drama inspired by the writings of Bruce Lee. He’s still recovering.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sakeina Syed
title: South Asian College Students Are Fake Marrying for the Vibes
description: Across North American schools, South Asian students are holding elaborately planned pretend weddings with the pomp and circumstance of real ones.
content: Bilal Nasir rode into his wedding on a bejeweled white horse, wearing a gleaming golden sherwani. He was surrounded by an entourage of his friends in coordinated outfits, dancing to the beat of a dhol, a two-sided drum. Light streamed out from the venue, Low Library at Columbia University, welcoming the crisp spring air on the evening of March 3.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: A Long-Shot Candidate’s Defense of Trump Could Undermine the Rule of Law
description: Vivek Ramaswamy is the lone Republican rival of Donald Trump to wholeheartedly claim the federal indictment is a Democratic attempt to jail the political opposition.
content: In the overheated basement of the Thunder Bay Grille in Davenport, Iowa, on Thursday night, Vivek Ramaswamy, the entrepreneur turned Republican presidential candidate, tried out a new opening for his well-practiced stump speech.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: Prestigious Rose Breeder Names Its New Bloom for a Black Gardener
description: For more than 60 years, David Austin Roses has named new varieties after historical British figures, all of them white. The Dannahue, which honors Danny Clarke, changed that.
content: For more than 60 years, David Austin Roses has bred the world’s most prestigious blooms. They are the Air Jordans, the Birkin bags, the Steinway pianos of roses, and have become what we know, smell and delight in as the modern English rose.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: SATURDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer and Chelsia Rose Marcius
title: What a Commissioner’s Abrupt Exit Says About the N.Y.P.D. Under Adams
description: The next N.Y.P.D. commissioner will have to contend with the mayor, a wary police force eager for clear leadership and a city worried about both crime and the use of force.
content: If Commissioner Keechant Sewell, head of the nation’s largest police force, wanted to promote an investigator to first-grade detective, she had to clear it with City Hall, according to her former top uniformed officer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: Listen Early to This American Life: Father’s Day
description: And the best of the archive, found in our new audio app.
content: The New York Times Audio app includes podcasts, narrated articles from the newsroom and other publishers, and exclusive new shows that we’re making available to readers for a limited time. Download the audio app here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Cain Miller
title: Everyone Says Social Media Is Bad for Teens. Proving It Is Another Thing.
description: Parents, scientists and the surgeon general are worried. But there isn’t even a shared definition of what social media is.
content: There have been increasingly loud public warnings that social media is harming teenagers’ mental health — most recently from the United States surgeon general — adding to many parents’ fears about what all the time spent on phones is doing to their children’s brains.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shaila Dewan
title: Consent Decrees Force Changes to Policing. But Do Reforms Last?
description: The Minneapolis Police may agree to court-enforced federal oversight. Experts say it can lead to improvements, though defining success can be difficult.
content: As demonstrations over police brutality rocked the country in 2020 following the death of George Floyd, Newark was held up as a model of police reform, a department so transformed by federal intervention that its officers had not fired a single shot that year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danielle Friedman
title: How to Exercise When It’s Humid
description: Working out in muggy weather can be brutal. Here are four ways to survive and thrive when it feels like a sauna outside.
content: Anyone who has gone for a jog on a hot, muggy day knows how miserable it can be — not only because your shirt is glued to your back, experts say, but also because humidity makes exercise much more challenging.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Anthes
title: The New War on Bad Air
description: A century ago, a well-ventilated building was considered good medicine. But by the time Covid-19 arrived, our buildings could barely breathe. How did that happen? And how do we let the fresh air back in?
content: In January 1912, in the depths of a New York City winter, an unusual new apartment complex opened on the Upper East Side.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danielle Trussoni
title: Murders, Curses, and the Greatest Horror Movie of All Time
description: The Golden Age of Hollywood — its patina darkened by evil — comes alive in Craig Russell’s new novel, “The Devil’s Playground.”
content: Can a film be cursed? Or is it the system behind the film — Hollywood and all its many shades of corruption — that’s toxic? It’s a central question of Craig Russell’s excellent, engrossing historical horror novel, one that explores the symbiosis of power and evil in the Golden Age of Hollywood.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael J. de la Merced
title: Investor and His Hedge Fund Are Rocked by Sex Assault Allegations
description: After accusations were published in Britain, Crispin Odey was severed from his own investment firm, which is now dissolving itself.
content: For three decades, Crispin Odey stood above London’s financial community, a larger-than-life financial mogul who was known for taking huge bets — and raking in big profits when they proved right.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Kirsch
title: Your Intentions for the Summer
description: Take some seasonal inspiration from what readers of The Morning are planning.
content: Years ago, I received a voicemail from the neighborhood cobbler telling me my shoes were ready to pick up. The message was perfunctory, left by the shop owner, a usually grumpy guy who sounded like his usually grumpy self. But instead of ending with “OK, bye” or “have a good day” or some other cliché, he signed off with “Enjoy your time.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: To Jail or Not to Jail
description: Rough sledding for Citizen Trump.
content: WASHINGTON — Studying “Hamlet,” the revenge play about a rotten kingdom, I tried for years to fathom Hamlet’s motives, state of mind, family web, obsessions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Carballo
title: Woman Accused of Killing Mother on Bali Trip Pleads Guilty
description: In an agreement with federal prosecutors, Heather Mack, 27, pleaded guilty to one count of conspiring to kill a U.S. national in the 2014 death of her mother.
content: A Chicago woman accused of conspiring to kill her mother and putting her body in a suitcase while on vacation in Bali nearly a decade ago pleaded guilty in federal court on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kristof
title: It’s Easy to Feel Righteous in the Trump Era. Liberals, Beware.
description: Conservatives are so wrong so often that they are pumping us liberals full of worrying smugness.
content: It was easy for my generation of baby boomer liberals to be humble, because we had much to be humble about.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel E. Slotnik
title: Jack McNally, N.Y.P.D. Detective Turned Defense Sleuth, Dies at 89
description: After he helped collar the men behind New York City’s biggest jewel heist, he worked as a private investigator for defendants like O.J. Simpson and Patty Hearst.
content: Jack McNally, who as a police detective in 1964 made the first arrest in the most audacious jewel theft in New York City history, and who then became a private investigator for famous defense lawyers like F. Lee Bailey and worked on behalf of clients like O.J. Simpson, died on May 28. He was 89.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abdi Latif Dahir
title: Uganda School Attack Leaves at Least 37 Dead
description: The authorities attribute the attack, one of the deadliest in years, to the Allied Democratic Forces, an extremist group based in neighboring Congo.
content: At least 37 people were killed — many of them students — and eight others were wounded when militants with an extremist group attacked a secondary school in western Uganda, the authorities said on Saturday, in one of the deadliest terrorist attacks in the East African nation in years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alix Strauss
title: The Tempestuous Lives of Secondhand Furniture
description: E-commerce sites like Facebook Marketplace have given unloved pieces a second (or third?) chance at a new beginning, and a provenance they would never have had.
content: In the summer of 2019, Jacqueline Lobel, a 33-year-old TV producer, was scrolling through Craigslist, optimistically hoping to buy a dining room table that would fit into a slightly dark space in the large studio apartment she had just moved into in Ditmas Park, Brooklyn.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Norimitsu Onishi and Renaud Philippe
title: ‘The Fires Here Are Unstoppable’
description: The first foreign firefighters to reach Quebec amid Canada’s worst wildfire season on record said that some of the blazes were 100 times bigger than any they had ever seen.
content: An out-of-control fire was advancing rapidly toward a logging road on Tuesday afternoon, tearing through Canada’s immense — and highly flammable — boreal forest with a force and intensity bewildering to a team of French firefighters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hiaasen
title: Coming of Age in the Sunshine State
description: Before Disney arrived, Central Florida was the hub of the citrus industry. Anne Hull takes us there in her memoir, “Through the Groves.”
content: Whatever it meant to be a Floridian while I was growing up is no longer accessible as an identity. Too many beautiful places have been drained dry, or buried beneath concrete. That’s what happens when the population of your home state explodes almost sevenfold in your lifetime.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana G. Smith
title: How to Soothe a Bad Sunburn
description: Experts recommend the best treatments for pain, peeling, blisters and swelling.
content: Oops. It’s the first day of your beach vacation and you stayed out in the sun a little (or a lot) too long. Now your skin is paying the price and you’re in need of some relief.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher F. Schuetze
title: Uruguay Has a Large Bronze Nazi Eagle. It’s Turning It Into a Dove.
description: The artifact, once part of a German warship, was recovered by a private venture off Uruguay’s coast in 2006. It’s been the subject of a legal battle for years.
content: An approximately 700-pound bronze Nazi eagle that once adorned a German warship and in recent years became the subject of a court case in Uruguay will be melted down and turned into a dove, the South American nation’s president said on Friday, a move that he said would transform a symbol of “violence and war” into one of “peace and unity.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marina Harss
title: It’s Story Time at Ballet Theater, With a Best Seller Twist
description: Christopher Wheeldon’s “Like Water for Chocolate” is a new kind of endeavor for the company: a full-length work based on a contemporary novel and popular film.
content: After tasting a dish infused with rose petals, a young woman experiences an erotic awakening so intense that she gallops off with a passing soldier. Another woman feels such love for her sister’s child that she develops the ability to nurse him from her own breast. Two lovers come together in an embrace so passionate that it causes them to spontaneously combust. Such magical occurrences arrive at regular intervals in “Like Water for Chocolate,” the 1989 novel by the Mexican writer Laura Esquivel that has now inspired a ballet by Christopher Wheeldon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: Biden Again Has Union Support. But the Unions Look Different This Time.
description: At a rally on Saturday hosted by the A.F.L.-C.I.O., President Biden enjoyed a warm reception. But changes in union membership mean that he still has work to do.
content: The public image of President Biden’s “Union Joe” persona rests largely on his longtime affiliations with labor unions representing police officers, firefighters and building-trade workers.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Approaches to Mental Illness
description: Readers respond to an Opinion guest essay by Daniel Bergner that questioned mandatory psychiatric treatment.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ernesto Londoño and Dan Simmons
title: Scathing Report on Police Leaves Minneapolis Reeling 3 Years After Floyd Murder
description: The Justice Department’s devastating findings left the city searching for next steps. Some residents found little closure.
content: The wounds of Minneapolis are far from healed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel L. Swarns
title: My Church Was Part of the Slave Trade. This Has Not Shaken My Faith.
description: Enslaved people have been largely left out of the origin story traditionally told about the emergence of Catholicism in the United States.
content: For more than a century, Catholic priests in Maryland held Black people in bondage. They were among the largest slaveholders in the state, and they prayed for the souls of the people they held captive even as they enslaved and sold their bodies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Julian E. Barnes and Natalia Yermak
title: Russia, Learning From Costly Mistakes, Shifts Battlefield Tactics
description: Moscow’s forces remain uneven. But while bracing for a counteroffensive, they have improved discipline, coordination and air support, foreshadowing a changing war.
content: KRAMATORSK, Ukraine — The team of soldiers had been out of their Ukrainian armored personnel carrier for only a matter of minutes when the tree line in front of them erupted in Russian gunfire. The dozen or so soldiers, sent to reinforce a trench, found themselves pinned down for hours.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Joni Mitchell Renaissance
description: A conversation about how the singer-songwriter was received during her career peak, and how she is remaking her own music in her later years.
content: Last summer at the Newport Folk Festival, fans of the singer Brandi Carlile were treated to a shocking surprise: a guest appearance by Joni Mitchell, who had been barely seen in public since recovering from an aneurysm in 2015. The joyful performance went old-school viral — a cross-generational feel-good sensation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Swanson and David McCabe
title: As U.S. and Chinese Officials Meet, Businesses Temper Their Hopes
description: Chief executives in the U.S. have long pushed for closer ties between the two countries. Now they just hope a rocky situation won’t get worse.
content: In a meeting in Beijing on Friday, China’s leader, Xi Jinping, traded warm smiles with Bill Gates and praised Mr. Gates as “the first American friend” he had met this year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eve Washington, Josh Katz and Tom Giratikanon
title: Top 10 Hardest and Easiest Spelling Bee Words, June 10-16
description: One of the words was so tough you could say it was radioactive.
content: Note: If you plan to play Spelling Bee’s Past Puzzles from the last week, this list may contain spoilers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hiroko Tabuchi
title: Study Compares Gas Stove Pollution to Secondhand Cigarette Smoke
description: One burner could raise indoor concentrations of benzene, which is linked to cancer risk, above levels that have prompted investigations when detected outdoors.
content: Using a single gas-stove burner can raise indoor concentrations of benzene, which is linked to cancer risk, to above what’s found in secondhand tobacco smoke and even to levels that have prompted local investigations when detected outdoors, according to a new study.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: No Culture for Alienated Men
description: Three models of masculine rebellion against the present age.
content: There were three important deaths recently: Ted Kaczynski, Silvio Berlusconi, Cormac McCarthy. A strange assortment of characters — the murderer who imagined himself a philosopher, the louche tycoon who created modern Western populism, the novelist who traded in biblical cadences without biblical reassurances.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: As Floodwaters Recede, Ukrainian Authorities Brace for Possible Disease Outbreaks
description: Concerns about waterborne illnesses pose another challenge for Ukrainian officials as they report slow progress in the early stages of a counteroffensive aimed at taking back Russian territory.
content: Nearly two weeks after the destruction of the Kakhovka dam in southeastern Ukraine the floodwaters are receding, but local officials are grappling with a new concern: the potential for outbreaks of waterborne diseases.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edward Wong and David Pierson
title: In China, Blinken Faces Clashing Agendas and a Question: Will Xi Show Up?
description: There’s much to talk about, but it’s not clear if it will be constructive. Meetings in Beijing will offer clues as to whether the two nations can smooth over tensions.
content: Antony J. Blinken landed in Beijing on Sunday morning, the first visit of a U.S. secretary of state to China since 2018. Tense relations have delayed the trip for months: He had intended to visit in February, but postponed after the Pentagon announced that a Chinese surveillance balloon was drifting across the continental United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Das
title: Three Teams Drop Out of Tour de Suisse After Cyclist’s Death
description: Gino Mäder’s Bahrain-Victorious squad and two other teams withdrew on Saturday, but organizers said they would complete the multistage race this weekend.
content: The Tour de Suisse cycling race resumed its multistage competition on Saturday, one day after a rider died from the injuries that he sustained in a crash during a high-speed mountain descent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joumana Khatib
title: Jezebels, Jazz and Rijsttafel
description: An editor recommends old and new books.
content: Dear readers,
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carol Rosenberg
title: Guantánamo Case Nearing a Decision on the Lasting Effects of Torture
description: A military judge heard from the final expert before he decides whether interrogations at Guantánamo were contaminated by years of C.I.A. detention.
content: By the time the prisoner accused of plotting the U.S.S. Cole bombing boasted about his role in the attack during interrogations at Guantánamo Bay, his memories and account were unreliable because of years of isolation and torture by the C.I.A., a former military interrogator testified Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: June 17, 2023
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, June 17, 2023.
content: A theater review on Friday about Robert Icke’s “The Doctor” misstated the year in which Arthur Schnitzler’s play “Professor Bernhardi,” on which “The Doctor” is based, was first performed. It was 1912, not 1922.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kasia Pilat
title: Bagging a New Generation
description: Baggu, a 16-year-old brand best known for its lightweight, foldable totes, is all over TikTok, where Gen Z fans are driving renewed interest.
content: Madi McCool was driving in downtown Philadelphia in the summer of 2020 when she first spotted it: a reusable cloth mask that was actually cute. It was baby blue, orange and white, with a distinctive, bold daisy pattern. It caught her eye immediately.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Kois
title: Lorrie Moore Will Not Confess
description: In a literary culture obsessed with self-disclosure, her brilliant short stories — and, now, a new novel — have always been about art, not autobiography.
content: “It’s like taking Milwaukee polka music and Italianizing it,” said Lorrie Moore. She was trying to explain to me what to expect from “La Traviata,” because I’d admitted I didn’t know that much about opera. “Do you find opera music beautiful when you hear it?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andy Newman
title: The Super in My Building Smokes in His Office. Can We Make Him Stop?
description: Short answer: Yes. And there are several ways you could go about it.
content: Q: The superintendent in my Manhattan prewar co-op building smokes all day long in his basement office. Smoking is not permitted in public spaces in the building, and all of the storage lockers that are just outside his office are constantly in smoky air. Anything we put in our storage locker will reek of cigarettes. The management company seems aware of the issue, but hasn’t stopped it. Maybe he is protected by a union? What can we do?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elie Levine
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ephrat Livni and Sarah Kessler
title: The Space Industry Is Taking Off. Space Law Is Still a Mystery.
description: Estimated to be worth about $460 billion, space businesses sometimes operate in legal black holes.
content: Elon Musk, Jeff Bezos and Richard Branson are racing to establish a presence in space. But what rights and obligations come with that?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Colbi Edmonds
title: I-95 in Philadelphia Expected to Reopen Within Two Weeks, Governor Says
description: Repairs were initially projected to take months. President Biden, who viewed the site on Saturday, said repairs would be finished “in record time.”
content: Gov. Josh Shapiro of Pennsylvania said on Saturday he was “confident” the portion of Interstate 95 in Philadelphia that collapsed last weekend will open within the next two weeks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: A Year After Dobbs, Advocates Push in the States for a Right to Birth Control
description: After Justice Clarence Thomas cast doubt on the Supreme Court decision that established a right to contraception, reproductive rights advocates are pressing for new protections at the state level.
content: One year after Justice Clarence Thomas said the Supreme Court should reconsider whether the Constitution affords Americans a right to birth control, Democrats and reproductive rights advocates are laying the groundwork for state-by-state battles over access to contraception — an issue they hope to turn against Republicans in 2024.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: Deadnaming Children Would Be Allowed Under School Policy
description: The leader of New Brunswick, Canada, is pushing his province to roll back a rule that required teachers to use a child’s preferred name and pronouns.
content: For almost two years, the province of New Brunswick has had a policy that required teachers to use the preferred names and genders of schoolchildren. But under a new policy introduced by the provincial leader, Premier Blaine Higgs, teachers must get the permission of parents if the child is under the age of 16.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Goldbaum and Safiullah Padshah
title: The Taliban Government Runs on WhatsApp. There’s Just One Problem.
description: The Taliban administration is stuck in a cat-and-mouse game with WhatsApp, which is off-limits to the nascent government because of U.S. sanctions.
content: Late one night two months ago, a team of Taliban security officers assembled on the outskirts of Afghanistan’s capital to prepare for a raid on an Islamic State hide-out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Suzanne Garfinkle-Crowell
title: Taylor Swift Has Rocked My Psychiatric Practice
description: What she has taught my patients about how to shake it off — and why nobody can calm down.
content: A few months ago I started joking that half of the treatments in my psychiatric practice had become “Taylor-based.” Many of my patients are adolescent girls and young women, and they have leaned on Taylor Swift as a kind of big sister through the daily agonies of being a teenage girl: unsteady friendships, the 24-hour firing squad of the internet, and of course, the endless longing to feel seen and valued. At the end of a session exploring these struggles, I’ve appreciated having her to keep my patients company the rest of the week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Cut the Cards, Perhaps
description: Ryan McCarty deals us a wild Saturday puzzle.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — This is Ryan McCarty’s 21st Saturday grid for The New York Times. He is one of our weekend regulars and a reliable constructor of the right kind of themeless workout, in my book. There are a handful of chewy debuts, great trivia and misdirection. There are also many touches, like dueling Romance languages in the southwest corner and thundering herds close to the center of the grid — little inside jokes that make me feel so clever for noticing (as if figuring out each entry in the first place isn’t cerebral enough). Each of us may pick up on something different — I see at least four more echoes and coincidences — and they’re all signs of the high art of puzzle-making.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Esau McCaulley
title: My Father Failed Me. Here’s How I Learned to Forgive Him.
description: Recognizing that my father had his own story allowed me to feel sympathy for him. What was at stake was not merely a father failing a son but a whole life crumbling.
content: I do not recall giving a single Father’s Day present. There were no cards hastily scribbled on colored paper during elementary school art class. My dad never received the barbecue apron with a silly message on it. My siblings cannot recall ever giving him gifts, either. This was no joint decision; it was an instinctive, shared response to trauma.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder
title: For PGA Tour Players, Betrayal and Confusion in Saudi Deal’s Wake
description: Members of America’s most famous golf tour thought they had a voice. Then came a surprise pact that could reshape the sport for years to come.
content: The U.S. Open winner Gary Woodland had lately sensed something different in professional golf.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: Black Bear Kills Arizona Man in ‘Highly Uncommon’ Attack
description: A 66-year-old man was having a morning coffee when a male black bear dragged him down an embankment. A neighbor shot and killed the animal, officials said.
content: An Arizona man having a morning coffee was fatally attacked on Friday by a male black bear that caught him unaware and dragged him down an embankment before a neighbor shot and killed it, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Fausset and Chase Castor
title: In Branson, Missouri, a Two-Wheeled Fix for the Commuter Blues
description: Much of the affordable housing in the tourist town is far from its famous entertainment strip. One solution: motor scooters offered for no money down.
content: Christie Schubert fired up her new motor scooter — Taiwanese-made, with mod midcentury Italian lines — and zoomed off to work on a Friday night in Branson, Mo., the ultraconservative tourist destination in the Ozarks that touts itself as one of the most “patriotic cities in America.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: My Two Cents
description: Joe DiPietro has some notes for you in his Sunday puzzle.
content: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: At Least 11 Killed as Storm Batters Brazil With Heavy Rain
description: The governor of Rio Grande do Sul said it was a priority “to find the missing and save people who may still be stranded by the floods.”
content: A winter storm slammed the southern Brazilian state of Rio Grande do Sul with torrential rain on Friday, killing 11 people, leaving 20 missing and prompting a helicopter search and rescue for victims wading in flooded neighborhoods, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Fahy and Santul Nerkar
title: Bob Huggins Resigns From West Virginia After Drunken Driving Charges
description: The men’s basketball coach, who was arrested Friday in Pittsburgh, had been suspended in May after he used a homophobic slur in a radio interview.
content: Bob Huggins, the men’s basketball coach at West Virginia, resigned late Saturday, a day after he was arrested in Pittsburgh and charged with driving under the influence.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Fatal Flaws Overlooked
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, June 17, 2023
content: “I cannot explain what was the intention here with this design. It’s the most puzzling building.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Woolfe
title: For Riccardo Muti, a Grand Sort-of-Finale in Chicago
description: The eminent maestro is ending an acclaimed 13-year run at the Chicago Symphony Orchestra. But with his successor not yet named, he’s sticking around.
content: The concert had ended, and Riccardo Muti, the music director of the Chicago Symphony, was walking out of Orchestra Hall when he saw a banner in the lobby and stopped in his tracks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Mazzetti, Ronen Bergman, Edward Wong and Vivian Nereim
title: Biden Administration Engages in Long-Shot Attempt for Saudi-Israel Deal
description: The president and his aides are pressing an aggressive diplomatic effort as Riyadh makes significant demands in exchange for normalization, including a nuclear deal and a robust U.S. security pact.
content: Shortly after his plane took off earlier this month from Riyadh, where he had held a lengthy meeting with Saudi Arabia’s crown prince, Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken called a different Middle East leader, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder
title: PGA Tour and LIV Golf Seek to Drop Litigation Against Each Other
description: Although the tour’s deal with the Saudi wealth fund has not closed, the request to a federal judge was a milestone in golf’s surprise détente.
content: The PGA Tour, LIV Golf and Saudi Arabia’s sovereign wealth fund asked a federal judge in California on Friday to dismiss the litigation that catapulted golf’s economic and power structure into the American court system.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Yaffe-Bellany and Matthew Goldstein
title: Binance Reaches Deal With Government to Avert U.S. Shutdown
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission agreed on a compromise with Binance that will keep the exchange open as it battles a fraud lawsuit.
content: The Securities and Exchange Commission reached a deal with Binance late Friday that would allow the world’s largest cryptocurrency exchange to keep operating in the United States and safeguard customer assets as the company battles a government lawsuit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffery C. Mays
title: Harlem City Council Election Tests Limits of Progressive Politics
description: Three moderate Democrats are running to replace Kristin Richardson Jordan, one of the city’s most left-leaning politicians, who is not seeking re-election.
content: Two years ago, when a democratic socialist narrowly won a crowded Democratic primary for a City Council seat in Harlem, some saw it as a sign that the historically Black neighborhood was becoming more politically progressive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Linda Qiu
title: Fact-Checking Nikki Haley on the Campaign Trail
description: The Republican presidential candidate has made inaccurate or misleading claims about abortion, trans youth, foreign policy and domestic issues.
content: Nikki Haley, the former governor of South Carolina, was the first prominent candidate to announce a challenge to former President Donald J. Trump’s bid for the Republican presidential nomination.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Places Most Affected by Remote Workers’ Moves Around the Country
description: Yes, many of them went to Austin. But consider the small Salisbury, Md., region, too.
content: Yes, many of them went to Austin. But consider the small Salisbury, Md., region, too.
source.name: The New York Times
